description: Coaching rubric for Sales Engineers focusing on technical accuracy, architecture design, and solution engineering

dimensions.name: Technical Accuracy
criteria: Accurately explains Prefect/Horizon architecture, features, and capabilities
Provides correct technical details without misinformation or exaggeration
Demonstrates deep understanding of product internals and limitations
Corrects any technical misstatements or misconceptions
Answers technical questions confidently and correctly

scoring.90-100: Excellent: All technical information is accurate and detailed. Demonstrates expert-level product knowledge. No errors or exaggerations. Confidently addresses even advanced technical questions with precision.
scoring.70-89: Good: Technical information is mostly accurate with minor gaps. Demonstrates strong product knowledge. Occasionally defers to follow-up for complex questions but provides accurate high-level answers.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Some technical inaccuracies or vague explanations. Limited depth of product knowledge. Makes unsupported claims or oversimplifies complex features.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Contains significant technical errors or misinformation. Weak product knowledge. Provides inaccurate answers or avoids technical questions entirely.

dimensions.name: Architecture Fit & Design
criteria: Assesses customer's existing tech stack, infrastructure, and integration points
Proposes architecture aligned with customer's constraints and requirements
Identifies potential technical challenges or blockers early
Offers multiple implementation approaches when appropriate
Discusses scalability, security, and operational considerations

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Thoroughly assesses customer environment, proposes thoughtful architecture tailored to their needs. Identifies risks proactively. Offers options with clear trade-offs. Addresses scalability and ops concerns comprehensively.
scoring.70-89: Good: Assesses key aspects of customer environment, proposes reasonable architecture. Identifies some risks. Discusses main implementation approaches. Covers major scalability or security concerns.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Limited assessment of customer environment, generic architecture proposal. Misses key technical challenges. Few implementation options discussed. Minimal coverage of non-functional requirements.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No assessment of customer environment, one-size-fits-all solution pitch. Doesn't identify risks or constraints. No discussion of scalability, security, or operational concerns.

dimensions.name: Problem-Solution Mapping
criteria: Clearly connects customer's technical pain points to Prefect capabilities
Maps customer workflows to concrete implementation patterns
Demonstrates how Prefect solves specific problems, not just feature listing
Uses customer's language and frames solutions in their context
Provides concrete examples or analogies to clarify complex concepts

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Every capability mentioned is directly tied to a customer pain point. Clear implementation paths for customer workflows. Uses customer-specific examples and their terminology. Complex concepts explained with relevant analogies.
scoring.70-89: Good: Most capabilities are connected to customer needs. Provides implementation guidance for main workflows. Uses some customer-specific framing. Explains most concepts clearly.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Weak connection between features and customer problems. Generic implementation guidance. Limited use of customer context. Some concepts explained poorly or not at all.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Feature dump with no connection to customer needs. No implementation guidance. Uses only Prefect jargon, not customer language. Fails to explain technical concepts.

dimensions.name: Technical Objection Resolution
criteria: Addresses technical concerns and objections with data and evidence
Acknowledges product limitations honestly and offers workarounds
Handles competitive technical comparisons factually and confidently
Uses proof points, benchmarks, or customer examples to support claims
Knows when to escalate complex questions to product/engineering

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Addresses all technical objections with evidence-based responses. Honest about limitations with practical workarounds. Confident in competitive positioning. Uses data and customer proof points effectively. Knows when to escalate appropriately.
scoring.70-89: Good: Addresses most technical objections adequately. Reasonably honest about limitations. Handles competitive questions well. Uses some proof points. Escalates when needed.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Some technical objections left unresolved or addressed poorly. Defensive about limitations. Weak competitive responses. Few proof points used. Doesn't know when to escalate.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Avoids technical objections or provides incorrect answers. Dismisses limitations or overpromises. Poor competitive handling. No proof points. Never escalates even when should.

dimensions.name: Collaboration with AE
criteria: Supports AE's selling motion without taking over the call
Reinforces business value and ROI messaging from technical perspective
Hands off to AE for commercial/contractual discussions
Aligns technical discovery with AE's qualification framework
Helps AE advance deal with technical validation and proof points

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Perfect balance of technical depth and AE support. Reinforces business value consistently. Seamless handoffs on commercial topics. Aligned on discovery and qualification. Provides technical evidence that helps AE close.
scoring.70-89: Good: Supports AE well while providing technical expertise. Mentions business value. Mostly defers commercial topics. Generally aligned on discovery. Helps advance deal technically.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Occasionally steps on AE's toes or goes off-script. Limited business value framing. Handles some commercial questions that should go to AE. Not fully aligned on discovery approach.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Takes over call from AE, pure technical focus with no business value. Answers pricing/contract questions inappropriately. Not aligned with AE on discovery or deal strategy.
